b9ce391e970ede27e9eb0c3f6ef3f274 (02:12): Does anybody know if ROS's PnP/USB support is good enough to get the FTDI USB<->Serial chip working?
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:13): about USB u should talk with fireball he just vanced to the bed
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:13): PnP u should talk with hpoussin
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:13): none of them are here
b9ce391e970ede27e9eb0c3f6ef3f274 (02:13): Oh well.
b9ce391e970ede27e9eb0c3f6ef3f274 (02:14): Thanks. ROS sure has come a long way by the looks of it.
b9ce391e970ede27e9eb0c3f6ef3f274 (02:14): You guys have done an amazing job.
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:14): we are working getting it futhers
b9ce391e970ede27e9eb0c3f6ef3f274 (02:15): Also, has anybody thought about taking the NTFS implementation from Linux and building a wrapper to make it an IFS driver?
b9ce391e970ede27e9eb0c3f6ef3f274 (02:15): That may be a good goal for port 0.3.x...
b9ce391e970ede27e9eb0c3f6ef3f274 (02:15): s/port/post/
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:16): I think of it time to time
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:16): when I count the negtive with the positve sides
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:16): the negtives wins
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:16): like it is bad idea
b9ce391e970ede27e9eb0c3f6ef3f274 (02:17): Just out of curiosity, why?
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:17): and u will lost alot speed and other stuff
b9ce391e970ede27e9eb0c3f6ef3f274 (02:17): Do you mean from the translation layer or just that NTFS has more overhead than FAT?
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:17): and windows and linux filesystem stack is alot diffent
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:17): the translations layers
b9ce391e970ede27e9eb0c3f6ef3f274 (02:18): I don't know much about the Linux kernel (at least, not these days). I am familiar with the BSD kernel architectures thoughh.

b9ce391e970ede27e9eb0c3f6ef3f274 (02:18): Well, it could be a gradual thing. I don't mean keep Linux file system semantics, but mimmick the Linux bio stuff in terms of IRP's until the code can slowly be changed. Thats one idea.
b9ce391e970ede27e9eb0c3f6ef3f274 (02:18): Or do you think ROS should have a from-scratch NTFS driver?
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:19): we have partly ntfs drv in ros
b9ce391e970ede27e9eb0c3f6ef3f274 (02:19): Really?
b9ce391e970ede27e9eb0c3f6ef3f274 (02:19): Wow. Didn't realize that.
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:19): I do not how well it is working
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:19): or it works at all
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:19): myg : our usb stack is from linux
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:20): our tcp/ip stack is from bsd
b9ce391e970ede27e9eb0c3f6ef3f274 (02:20): Yeah, I know.
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:20): it was alot work getting them inplace
b9ce391e970ede27e9eb0c3f6ef3f274 (02:20): True. I think the BSD stack was a good idea though.
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:20): but the work are not finish yet
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:21): Arty have done great work with tcp/ip stack
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:21): and fireball with usb stack
b9ce391e970ede27e9eb0c3f6ef3f274 (02:21): If we wanted to do NTFS like MS Windows does somebody would need to implement the LFS API's in the kernel.
2741b69c3b371bf320f870bfe5de76c7 (02:21): is head booting for anyone else?
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:22): it boting now
2741b69c3b371bf320f870bfe5de76c7 (02:22): hmm i'll make clean
b9ce391e970ede27e9eb0c3f6ef3f274 (02:22): In NT there is a generic API for journalling (a bit like Linux's jbd) stuff actually in NTOSKRNL.
b9ce391e970ede27e9eb0c3f6ef3f274 (02:22): Not sure if those API's are documented.
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:22): arty u must make a clean build getting it boot again
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:22): u can try the iso achive
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:22): to be sure it does
2741b69c3b371bf320f870bfe5de76c7 (02:22): oh don't know where it is
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:23): http://svn.reactos.org/iso
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:23): there is the iso archive
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:23): myg : we can look at captive drv as well
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:23): how he done some stuff
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:24): some stuff is right
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:24): some other part bit wrong
b9ce391e970ede27e9eb0c3f6ef3f274 (02:24): GL: Thats a good idea. What is the licensing of the captive stuff.... can it be integrated (legally) in ROS?
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:24): it comes from ros ntokrnl
2741b69c3b371bf320f870bfe5de76c7 (02:24): imo the main thing that keeps us from merging captive is heavy reliance on glib
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:24): with havy modifcations
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:24): arty not only
b9ce391e970ede27e9eb0c3f6ef3f274 (02:25): Hmmm. So (never having looked at the captive stuff) I take it the code they implemented does not use the Rtl* stuff?
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:25): he implement whole adv* into ntosnkrln and ntdll
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:25): it use rtl stuff
b9ce391e970ede27e9eb0c3f6ef3f274 (02:25): So what does it do with glib?
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:25): he implement all api he need into ntoskrnl
2741b69c3b371bf320f870bfe5de76c7 (02:26): memory allocation, string handling etc
2741b69c3b371bf320f870bfe5de76c7 (02:26): he used glib pervasively
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:26): yes he invent own cc
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:26): with glib
2741b69c3b371bf320f870bfe5de76c7 (02:26): which is ok considering he was going for using it in userland on linux
b9ce391e970ede27e9eb0c3f6ef3f274 (02:26): hmmm. Well, I should go look at it. that may be a good project for me if I can find the time.... de glib-ize the code.
b9ce391e970ede27e9eb0c3f6ef3f274 (02:27): Don't know if I have the time for getting it into the ROS kernel...
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:27): I found one fualt in ros ntoskrnl thx to cabitve source revivew and I fix it
b9ce391e970ede27e9eb0c3f6ef3f274 (02:28): I suppose that would be another interesting goal. Getting MS's NTFS.SYS running under ROS.
2741b69c3b371bf320f870bfe5de76c7 (02:28): myg: i think the first part of that goal is getting some open source fs drivers that work on windows working unmodified on linux
2741b69c3b371bf320f870bfe5de76c7 (02:28): on reactos sorry
2741b69c3b371bf320f870bfe5de76c7 (02:29): if that happens, I think we'll be much closer
b9ce391e970ede27e9eb0c3f6ef3f274 (02:29): I don't know of too many..... There was a closed-source port of XFS a while ago. Don't know what happened to it.
b9ce391e970ede27e9eb0c3f6ef3f274 (02:29): I know that ClearCase's MVFS is not a good place to start. :)
2741b69c3b371bf320f870bfe5de76c7 (02:30): myg: there are a few; ext2, cramfs, afs
b9ce391e970ede27e9eb0c3f6ef3f274 (02:30): arty: do any of them work under ROS?
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:30): bfs if i rember right
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:31): for we do not have a cache mangers
6c30c79bc333fa9f0c9a01c4b03008d3 (02:31): to start with
